subject: Computer Networks
description: Questions on networking protocols, models, architectures, and security

topics.name: Network Models
topics.description: OSI and TCP/IP models, layers and their functions

questions.question: What are the seven layers of the OSI model?
questions.answer: Physical, Data Link, Network, Transport, Session, Presentation, and Application layers.
questions.explanation: The OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) model is a conceptual framework used to understand network interactions in seven layers.

questions.question: What is the main difference between the OSI model and the TCP/IP model?
questions.answer: The OSI model has seven layers, while the TCP/IP model has four layers. The TCP/IP model is more practical and widely implemented, while the OSI model is more theoretical.
questions.explanation: The TCP/IP model combines several OSI layers and is the foundation of the modern Internet.

questions.question: Which of the following protocols operates at the Transport layer?
questions.answer: TCP
questions.explanation: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) operates at the Transport layer (Layer 4) of the OSI model and provides reliable, connection-oriented data delivery.

questions.question: What is the function of the Network layer in the OSI model?
questions.answer: The Network layer is responsible for packet forwarding, routing, and addressing. It handles the transfer of data across different networks.
questions.explanation: This layer determines the best path for data to travel from source to destination, often across multiple networks.

questions.question: Which protocol operates at the highest layer of the TCP/IP model?
questions.answer: HTTP
questions.explanation: HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol) operates at the Application layer, which is the highest layer in the TCP/IP model.

questions.question: What is the purpose of encapsulation in networking?
questions.answer: Encapsulation is the process of adding headers and sometimes trailers to data as it moves down the protocol stack, preparing it for transmission across the network.
questions.explanation: Each layer adds its own information, allowing the corresponding layer on the receiving end to process it properly.

topics.name: Internet Protocols
topics.description: TCP/IP, UDP, HTTP, and other core internet protocols

questions.question: What is the difference between TCP and UDP?
questions.answer: TCP is connection-oriented, reliable, and provides error checking and flow control. UDP is connectionless, unreliable, but faster with less overhead.
questions.explanation: TCP is used when reliability is critical (e.g., web browsing, email), while UDP is used when speed is more important (e.g., streaming, gaming).

questions.question: What is a TCP three-way handshake?
questions.answer: A three-way handshake is the method TCP uses to establish a connection. It involves SYN, SYN-ACK, and ACK messages exchanged between client and server.
questions.explanation: This process synchronizes sequence numbers and ensures both sides are ready for data transmission.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a version of the IP protocol?
questions.answer: IPv7
questions.explanation: IPv4 and IPv6 are widely used versions of the Internet Protocol. IPv5 was an experimental protocol that never became a standard. IPv7 does not exist.

questions.question: What is the purpose of ICMP?
questions.answer: Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is used for error reporting and operational information about IP packet processing. It's used by tools like ping and traceroute.
questions.explanation: ICMP messages typically report errors in packet processing or provide network diagnostic information.

questions.question: What is the difference between HTTP and HTTPS?
questions.answer: HTTPS (HTTP Secure) is HTTP with encryption. It uses SSL/TLS protocols to encrypt the communication between the browser and server.
questions.explanation: HTTPS provides secure communication for sensitive information like passwords, credit card details, and personal information.

questions.question: How does TCP handle reliable data delivery?
questions.answer: TCP ensures reliable delivery through sequence numbers, acknowledgments, checksums, and retransmissions of lost packets.
questions.explanation: If a packet is lost or corrupted, TCP will detect this and retransmit the missing data, ensuring all data is delivered correctly.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the ARP protocol?
questions.answer: Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) maps IP addresses to MAC addresses in a local network.
questions.explanation: When a device wants to communicate with another device on the same network, it needs to know the MAC address corresponding to the IP address.

topics.name: Routing and Switching
topics.description: Network routing algorithms, protocols, and switching methods

questions.question: What is the difference between a router and a switch?
questions.answer: A switch operates at the Data Link layer (Layer 2) and forwards frames within a single network using MAC addresses. A router operates at the Network layer (Layer 3) and can route packets between different networks using IP addresses.
questions.explanation: Switches create a local network, while routers connect different networks together.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a routing table?
questions.answer: A routing table contains information about network destinations and how to reach them, including the next hop, interface, and metrics.
questions.explanation: Routers use routing tables to determine the best path for forwarding packets toward their destinations.

questions.question: What is the difference between RIP and OSPF?
questions.answer: RIP (Routing Information Protocol) is a distance-vector protocol that uses hop count as its metric. OSPF (Open Shortest Path First) is a link-state protocol that uses bandwidth-based cost metrics and can handle larger networks more efficiently.
questions.explanation: OSPF is generally more scalable and converges faster than RIP in large networks.

questions.question: What is a default gateway?
questions.answer: A default gateway is the device (usually a router) that forwards packets from the local network to destinations in other networks when no other route is specified.
questions.explanation: When a device wants to communicate with a device on another network, it sends the packet to the default gateway if it doesn't have a specific route.

questions.question: What is the spanning tree protocol (STP) used for?
questions.answer: STP prevents loops in Ethernet networks with redundant paths by selectively blocking ports to ensure a loop-free topology.
questions.explanation: Without STP, broadcast storms, multiple frame deliveries, and MAC table instability could occur in networks with redundant links.

topics.name: Network Security
topics.description: Security protocols, firewalls, VPNs, and threats

questions.question: What is a firewall?
questions.answer: A firewall is a network security device that monitors and filters incoming and outgoing network traffic based on an organization's security policies.
questions.explanation: Firewalls act as a barrier between a trusted network and untrusted networks, such as the Internet.

questions.question: What is a VPN and what is its purpose?
questions.answer: A Virtual Private Network (VPN) creates a secure, encrypted connection over a less secure network, like the internet. It allows users to send and receive data as if their devices were directly connected to a private network.
questions.explanation: VPNs are commonly used to access region-restricted websites, shield browsing activity from public Wi-Fi, and protect sensitive data.

questions.question: What is a DDoS attack?
questions.answer: A Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack attempts to make a service unavailable by flooding it with traffic from multiple sources.
questions.explanation: DDoS attacks overwhelm servers, networks, or services with excessive requests, preventing legitimate users from accessing them.

questions.question: What is the difference between symmetric and asymmetric encryption?
questions.answer: Symmetric encryption uses the same key for encryption and decryption. Asymmetric encryption uses a public key for encryption and a private key for decryption.
questions.explanation: Symmetric encryption is faster but requires secure key exchange. Asymmetric encryption is slower but solves the key distribution problem.

questions.question: What is a man-in-the-middle attack?
questions.answer: A man-in-the-middle (MITM) attack occurs when an attacker secretly relays and possibly alters communication between two parties who believe they are directly communicating with each other.
questions.explanation: The attacker can intercept, read, and modify data without either party knowing, often by impersonating both sides of the connection.

questions.question: What is the purpose of TLS/SSL in network security?
questions.answer: Transport Layer Security (TLS) and its predecessor, Secure Sockets Layer (SSL), are cryptographic protocols that provide secure communication over a network by encrypting data and authenticating the connection.
questions.explanation: TLS/SSL is commonly used to secure web browsing (HTTPS), email, file transfers, and other applications.

questions.question: What does IEEE 802.11 refer to?
questions.answer: IEEE 802.11 is a set of standards for wireless local area network (WLAN) communications, commonly known as Wi-Fi.
questions.explanation: Different versions (like 802.11a, 802.11b, 802.11g, 802.11n, 802.11ac, and 802.11ax) define various speeds and frequencies.

questions.question: What is the difference between WEP, WPA, and WPA2?
questions.answer: WEP (Wired Equivalent Privacy) is an older, insecure encryption protocol. WPA (Wi-Fi Protected Access) improved security over WEP. WPA2 further enhanced security with AES encryption. WPA3 is the newest standard with even stronger protection.
questions.explanation: WEP can be easily cracked, WPA was a temporary solution, and WPA2/WPA3 are currently recommended for secure Wi-Fi networks.

questions.question: What is a service set identifier (SSID)?
questions.answer: An SSID is the name that identifies a wireless network. Devices use this name to connect to the specific network.
questions.explanation: SSIDs can be hidden for security purposes, though this provides minimal actual security benefit.

questions.question: What wireless technology is commonly used for short-range communications between devices like headphones and smartphones?
questions.answer: Bluetooth
questions.explanation: Bluetooth is designed for short-range wireless communications (typically up to 10 meters) with relatively low power consumption.

questions.question: What is the main difference between 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz Wi-Fi?
questions.answer: 2.4 GHz has better range but lower speed and is more prone to interference. 5 GHz offers faster speeds and less interference but has a shorter range and poorer penetration through walls.
questions.explanation: Many modern routers are dual-band, offering both frequencies to balance range and speed requirements.
